body.p: C’est toujours avec un égal plaisir que je reçois vos lettres: celle du 1 juillet n. st. est par conséquent du nombre. Comme vous voyez, je ne suis point à Tsarskoé-Sélo: les grandes chaleurs que nous avons eues ont été cause qu'il y a précisément un mois aujourd'hui que j'en suis partie, et ce n'est qu'ici au bord de la mer qu'on a pu respirer. Mais imaginez-vous, madame, ce qui vient d'arriver sur cette mer. Le fils aîné du feu prince George, mon oncle, le prince Auguste de Holstein, m'ayant prié de lui permettre de faire une campagne sur mon escadre qui croise cet été, comme de coutume, dans la Baltique, partit sur un de mes vaisseaux de guerre nommé l’Ezéchiel, il y a de cela à peu près trois semaines, de Kronstadt. Après avoir été retenu par les vents contraires, le 3 de ce mois à 5 heures du soir on aperçut sur le vaisseau le phare de Reval; le prince n'eut rien de plus pressé, quoiqu'il ne fût point d'un naturel fort vif, que de grimper sur un des mâts; mais en redescendant il se laissa choir, tomba sur un des bords du vaisseau la tête en bas, et de là dans la mer, où il se noya, malgré quatre nageurs qui se plongèrent dans la mer pour le sauver. On croisa plusieurs jours pour retrouver au moins son corps, mais jamais on n'a pu: vous ne sauriez croire la peine que cet accident aussi malheureux nous cause à tous. Son frère est à l'armée. On dit qu'il est d'un courage téméraire: il fait le coup de pistolet avec les Turcs; j'ai déjà prié le maréchal de l'empêcher de se faire tuer.Compare with Catherine's letter of 14 July 1774 to Gustav III of Sweden, in which she informs him too of the death of Wilhelm August, son of their shared uncle Georg Ludwig (Catherine II et Gustave III, pp. 54-55). Vous savez déjà, madame, que ce maréchal a commencé la campagne par la défaite au-delà du Danube d'un corps turc de quarante mille hommes et la prise de 29 pièces de canons fondus par M. Tott, brigadier du roi très-chrétien, avec 108 drapeaux et deux camps turcs. Il y a eu encore un autre corps turc battu entre Roustchouk et Tourtoukaï.On the very day this letter was written, 10/21 July 1774, Field-Marshal P.A. Rumyantsev secured for Russia the advantageous peace treaty of Kuchuk Kainardzhi. For this diplomatic feat, and for the military one of crossing the Danube as mentioned in this letter, Rumyantsev was rewarded upon his return to Moscow in 1775 with the honorific title of 'Zadunaisky' ('Задунайский' or 'beyond the Danube'). The successful crossing of the Danube was of great symbolic significance, as Russian forces had last done so under Svyatoslav in the 10th century.

Avant-hier enfin il a plu à sa majesté Suédoise de me tirer de l'incertitude au sujet de son voyage: il m'a envoyé un courrier pour m'instruire qu'il a remis ce voyage jusqu'à l'année prochaine.Gustav informed Catherine that he was postponing his visit, a change he attributed to the delayed arrival of the new duchess of Södermanland, in a letter of 7 July 1774 (NS) (Catherine II et Gustave III, pp. 52-53). He finally visited Russia in 1777. Dites-moi, je vous prie, si la duchesse de Mecklembourg, dont vous m'annoncez l'arrivée à Hambourg, est séparée d'avec son mari, ou n'est-ce qu'un voyage de plaisir? Il est très sûr que M. Moser est un des plus grands vilains que j'aie connus de mes jours; je ne crois pas cependant que les chagrins qu'il a donnés à la landgrave aient avancé ses jours: cette princesse était mourante tous les jours depuis neuf ans; on a trouvé son état décrit jour par jour par elle-même depuis ce temps.In a letter of 1 July 1774 (NS), Mme Bielke told Catherine that Moser had accelerated the death (on 30 March 1774) of Landgravine Karoline of Hesse-Darmstadt by causing her to quarrel with her husband. Catherine greatly regretted the death of the landgravine, with whom she had just become acquainted during the latter's visit to St. Petersburg. As she wrote to Mme Bielke on 9 April 1774: 'j'ai perdu la landgrave, et je suis inconsolable de cette perte' (Sbornik Imperatorskago Russkago Istoricheskago Obshchestva, xiii, p. 400).

Je suis très curieuse d'apprendre la suite du voyage de la duchesse de Sudermanie; j'espère qu'on ne la fera pas attendre aussi longtemps pour son débarquement que pour son départ; les vaisseaux suédois ont été quinze jours à Wismar avant qu'on ait envoyé avertir mon oncle de faire partir sa fille d’Eutin.Gustav III consulted Catherine in a letter of 22 August 1773 (NS) on the choice of Hedwig Elisabeth Charlotte of Holstein for his brother Charles of Södermanland; the other candidate for Charles's hand, Louise of Hesse-Darmstadt, was at the time in St. Petersburg with her mother and sisters, for the wedding of her sister Wilhelmine to the future Paul I. In her reply of 29 August 1773, Catherine expressed her support for the choice of Louise of Hesse-Darmstadt, who had been suggested by Frederick II of Prussia, but Catherine nonetheless acquiesced to the choice of Hedwig Charlotte of Holstein (Catherine II et Gustave III, pp. 42-46).

closer.signed: Mais en voilà assez pour aujourd’hui, n’est il pas vrai? Adieu, aimez-moi toujours un peu.

body.p: I always receive your letters with equal pleasure: that of 1 July N.S. is therefore amongst that number. As you see, I am not at Tsarskoe Selo: the intense hot spell we had made me leave exactly a month ago today, and it was only here at the seaside that we could breathe. But can you imagine, madam, what just happened on this sea? The elder son of the late Prince George, my uncle, Prince Augustus of Holstein, had entreated me to allow him to go on campaign with my squadron, which is cruising this summer, as usual, in the Baltic. He departed from Kronstadt on one of my warships, named the Ezechiel, about three weeks ago. Having been detained by contrary winds, on the third of this month at 5 in the evening, they sighted from the ship the lighthouse of Reval. Although he was not of a particularly lively nature, the prince was in a great hurry to climb one of the masts. But on the way down he let himself fall, hit one of the sides of the ship head-first, and from there went into the sea, where he was drowned, in spite of four swimmers who dove into the sea to save him. They cruised for several days to find his body at least, but they could not: you cannot believe how much such an unhappy accident grieves us all. His brother is with the army. They say that he is of audacious courage: he fights the Turks with pistols. I have already entreated the field marshal to keep him from getting himself killed. You already know, madam, that this field marshal began the campaign by defeating on the other side of the Danube a Turkish corps of forty thousand men and by taking 29 cannons cast by Mr. Tott, brigadier to the Most Christian King, along with 108 flags and two Turkish camps. Another Turkish corps was beaten between Ruse and Tutrakan.

The day before yesterday His Swedish Majesty was finally pleased to release me from my uncertainty regarding his voyage: he sent me a courier to inform me that he has put off that voyage until next year. Tell me, I pray you, whether the duchess of Mecklenburg, who, you tell me, has arrived in Hamburg, has separated from her husband, or is it just a pleasure trip? It is certain that Mr. Moser is one of the greatest villains I have known in all my life. Yet I do not think that the grief he caused the landgravine hastened her death: the princess had been dying every day for nine years. They have since found her day-by-day description of her condition from that time on.

I am very curious to find out about the rest of the duchess of Sudermanland's voyage. I hope that she will not be made to wait as long to disembark as she was at her departure: the Swedish vessels spent fifteen days at Wismar before they sent anyone to notify my uncle to send his daughter from Eutin.

closer.signed: But that's enough for today, is it not? Farewell, carry on loving me a little.
